channel.title: Maggie Appleton
channel.description: A digital garden filled with visual essays, research notes, and experiments at the intersection of design, development, and anthropology.

item.title: Meet the Robowaiter APIs Serving Us Data
item.content:encoded: Everything you need to know about what API's are and how they work

item.title: Organic, Local, Artisan Data Storage
item.content:encoded: Data is currently dislocated – our narratives and metaphors around it try to convince us it is immaterial

item.title: A Short History of Bi-Directional Links
item.content:encoded: Seventy years ago we dreamed up links that would allow us to create two-way, contextual conversations. Why don't we use them on the web?

item.title: A Shelfish Starter Guide to Databases
item.content:encoded: The absolute minimum you need to know about data storage

item.title: A Brief Introduction to Digital Anthropology
item.content:encoded: A discipline at the intersection of cultural anthropology and binary logic

item.title: How to Draw Invisible Programming Concepts: Part I
item.content:encoded: A case study showing how I make illustrations for abstract programming concepts

item.title: A Brief History & Ethos of the Digital Garden
item.content:encoded: A newly revived philosophy for publishing personal knowledge on the web

item.content:encoded: Visualising the cultural narratives around cultured meat

item.title: Metaphors We Web By
item.content:encoded: A history of our metaphorical understanding of the web

item.content:encoded: How to build a digital garden without touching code

item.title: Paleolithic Nostalgia

item.title: Problematic Proteins

item.title: Why You Own an iPad and Still Can't Draw
item.content:encoded: The failure of drawing materials without mediums and meat

item.title: Tools for Thought as Cultural Practices, not Computational Objects

item.title: Transclusion and Transcopyright Dreams
item.content:encoded: The lost permissioning and copyright system of the Web

item.title: The Pattern Language of Project Xanadu
item.content:encoded: Project Xanadu as a pattern language, rather than a failed software project

item.title: Designing an “I Think You're Wrong” Button
item.content:encoded: Exploring ways to enable feedback, corrections, and constructive criticism on personal websites

item.content:encoded: A new role at an AI research lab working on tools for open-ended reasoning

item.title: Positioning Elements & Scrollytelling in CSS
item.content:encoded: Notes on how to use the position property in CSS to make scrollytelling stories

item.title: The Block-Paved Path to Structured Data
item.content:encoded: How block-based interfaces can help us create more structured data on the web

item.content:encoded: A collection of laws named for specific people in the field of programming

item.content:encoded: Questions I am often asked to answer

item.content:encoded: Narrative essays that I consider ideal models of the medium

item.content:encoded: The written version of my talk about bringing visual explanations and embodied knowledge to programming tools

item.content:encoded: A collection of observations on the rise of soft, sparkly, baby pink aesthetics among developers
